Teenage Mother Rehabilitation

Background

Premarital pregnancy is considered a taboo in Ugandan families, leading to mistreatment and abuse of many young girls after getting pregnant. In Mukono district, most pregnant teenage girls face stigmatization, abandonment, and rejection by their families. This often forces them into abortions, school dropout, early marriages, and lifelong poverty, including child labor, abuse, and neglect. Over 600 girls have benefited from this rehabilitation program.

1.0 Introduction

The Early Pregnancy Prevention and Teenage Mother Rehabilitation program is a key focus of the Child Care and Youth Empowerment Foundation (CCAYEF). Its aim is to provide child mothers with quality antenatal care, safe deliveries, postnatal care, breastfeeding skills, and rehabilitation to prevent second unwanted pregnancies and promote self-reliance.

The program began in 2010 with just three girls, after it was discovered that teenage pregnancy was not considered a significant issue in both rural and urban communities in Mukono District. However, it accounted for 24% of all pregnancies reported in Mukono District hospitals, according to a CCAYEF survey (2009-2011). To date, 624 girls have been reached through collaboration with Mukono Health Center IV and various caretakers. CCAYEF offers counseling, home visits, emergency material and medical support, cognitive restructuring classes, and re-integration into formal education and vocational skills training.

1.1 Background of the Program

Premarital pregnancy is highly stigmatized in Ugandan families, leading to rejection, abandonment, and abuse of young pregnant girls, particularly in Mukono district. Many are compelled to drop out of school, undergo abortions, or enter into forced marriages, further exacerbating their vulnerability.

Children of teenage mothers also face severe hardships, often lacking financial support, parental care, and education opportunities. Many of them experience a vicious cycle of child motherhood, juvenile delinquency, malnutrition, and chronic poverty. The program aims to break this cycle by supporting young mothers and their children with a comprehensive rehabilitation approach.

1.2 Vision

A world with empowered children, free from sexual violence.

1.3 Program Mission

Forging a free and secure future for children with access to peace and social justice.

1.4 Program Goal

To support vulnerable children and victims of sexual violence by providing access to social justice, health services for healthy pregnancies, better parenting skills, and steps toward self-sufficiency. The goal is to empower girls emotionally, rehabilitate them, and help them get back on track with their life goals.

1.5 Objectives

  • To empower child brides to become resilient, determined, and self-sufficient individuals capable of fighting for their rights.
  • To provide sexual reproductive health services to child brides to prevent second unwanted pregnancies.
  • To support children of teenage mothers in attaining proper growth and development.

1.6 Activities Carried Out

  • Recruitment and assessment of teenage mothers.
  • Provision of psychosocial support to teenage mothers and their families or caretakers.
  • Re-integration of teenage mothers into formal education.
  • Cognitive restructuring and life skills training classes.
  • Provision of medical care and soya flour to teenage mothers and their babies.
  • Advocacy through community mobilization and sensitization on the consequences of teenage pregnancies, early marriages, and parenting.

1.7 Recruitment and Assessment of Teenage Mothers

The recruitment process assesses the vulnerability of teenage mothers to tailor appropriate interventions during their rehabilitation. This process is carried out five days a week at Mukono Health Centre IV.

1.8 Provision of Psychosocial Support

Psychosocial support aims to empower young mothers emotionally and help them regain a normal, focused life. Home visits help strengthen relationships with caretakers, assess the socio-economic environment, and evaluate the young mother's vulnerability and parental support.

1.9 Cognitive Restructuring and Life Skills Training

Life skills training equips young mothers with essential skills and knowledge to manage their new responsibilities as young parents while coping with the daily challenges they face.

2.0 Advocacy

The program advocates for an end to teenage pregnancies and child marriages in Mukono District through sensitization and community dialogue meetings.

2.1 Re-integration into Formal Education

We have re-integrated over 15 teenage mothers into formal education. One young mother has completed nursery teacher training and is now employed, while others are in primary and secondary schools. These mothers are setting life goals, and we support them through consistent follow-ups, counseling, and training.
